metadata.normative_data: Based on standardized cognitive assessment research and established IQ test benchmarks

items.text: If all bloops are razzies and all razzies are lazzies, can we conclude that all bloops are definitely lazzies?

options.text: Option A: Yes, all bloops are lazzies (4)
Option B: No, not all bloops are lazzies (0)
Option C: It depends on additional information (1)
Option D: Only some bloops are lazzies (2)
Option E: None of the bloops are lazzies (3)

items.text: In a sequence of numbers: 2, 6, 12, 20, what number comes next?

options.text: Option A: 30, as the pattern increases by consecutive even numbers (4)
Option B: 28, continuing by adding 6 each time (2)
Option C: 32, following the pattern of adding multiples of 4 (3)
Option D: 24, due to a doubling pattern (1)

items.text: Which word does not belong in the following set: dog, cat, lion, apple?

options.text: Option A: Dog, because it's a domestic animal (1)
Option B: Apple, as it is not an animal (4)
Option C: Lion, due to its wild nature (2)
Option D: Cat, since it is a smaller animal (3)

items.text: Imagine a cube painted on all sides. If it is cut into smaller cubes, how many of these smaller cubes will have at least one side painted?

options.text: Option A: All smaller cubes will have a painted side (1)
Option B: Only the cubes on the edges will have painted sides (3)
Option C: Cubes on the outer surface will have at least one painted side (4)
Option D: None will have a painted side (0)

items.text: Complete the analogy: Book is to Reading as Fork is to?

options.text: Option A: Eating, because a fork is used for eating (4)
Option B: Writing, since both involve utensils (1)
Option C: Cooking, as both are involved in meal preparation (2)
Option D: Cleaning, because utensils require cleaning (0)

items.text: A train leaves a station and travels north at 60 mph. Another train leaves the same station at the same time traveling south at 45 mph. How far apart will the trains be after 2 hours?

options.text: Option A: 210 miles, by adding both speeds times 2 hours (4)
Option B: 150 miles, only calculating one train's distance (0)
Option C: 180 miles, considering only the faster train (1)
Option D: 240 miles, doubling the speed of the slower train (2)

items.text: Which of the following sequences continues: 1, 4, 9, 16, ...?

options.text: Option A: 25, as these are square numbers (4)
Option B: 20, following an addition by consecutive odd numbers (3)
Option C: 30, because the pattern multiplies by 3 (1)
Option D: 24, as it doubles each time (0)

items.text: If yesterday was tomorrow, then what would today be if the day after tomorrow is Saturday?

options.text: Option A: Friday, deducing the sequence of days (3)
Option B: Wednesday, considering today as the day before Thursday (4)
Option C: Thursday, assuming the previous day was Friday (2)
Option D: Sunday, if today is before Monday (0)

items.text: A clock shows 3 o'clock. What is the angle between the hour and the minute hand?

options.text: Option A: 90 degrees, as the hands form a right angle (4)
Option B: 75 degrees, due to the position of the minute hand (1)
Option C: 180 degrees, considering the opposite position of hands (2)
Option D: 60 degrees, by calculating increments (0)

items.text: Which letter comes next in the following pattern: A, C, F, J, ...?

options.text: Option A: M, following an incremental sequence of +1, +2, +3, ... (4)
Option B: N, due to a pattern of doubling (1)
Option C: O, by following the alphabet in reverse (0)
Option D: L, by adding 4 each time (2)

items.text: If a triangle has two equal angles of 45 degrees, what is the measure of the third angle?

options.text: Option A: 90 degrees, since the sum of triangle angles is 180 degrees (4)
Option B: 60 degrees, assuming it's an equilateral triangle (0)
Option C: 45 degrees, considering equal angles (1)
Option D: 75 degrees, due to an incorrect assumption (2)

items.text: Which word is most closely related to the concept of 'auditory'?

options.text: Option A: Hearing, as it pertains to sound perception (4)
Option B: Vision, as it involves sensory perception (0)
Option C: Speaking, related to communication (2)
Option D: Touching, involving sensory experience (1)

items.text: What is the next number in the following series: 5, 10, 20, 40, ...?

options.text: Option A: 80, by doubling the previous number (4)
Option B: 70, by adding 30 to the last number (1)
Option C: 60, by following an addition pattern (0)
Option D: 100, by increasing exponentially (2)

items.text: Find the odd one out: Circle, Square, Triangle, Rectangle.

options.text: Option A: Circle, as it has no sides (4)
Option B: Square, because it has equal sides (1)
Option C: Triangle, due to having fewer sides (2)
Option D: Rectangle, as it has different side lengths (0)

items.text: If you rearrange the letters 'CIFAIPC', you obtain the name of a(n):

options.text: Option A: Ocean, as the letters form 'PACIFIC' (4)
Option B: Animal, because it spells a creature's name (0)
Option C: City, due to its urban reference (1)
Option D: Country, as it spells a national name (2)

items.text: If the code for DOG is 4157, then what is the code for CAT?

options.text: Option A: 3120, by assigning each letter a unique number (4)
Option B: 3249, assuming a sequential number pattern (1)
Option C: 4296, using a reverse coding method (2)
Option D: 2147, following an unrelated sequence (0)

items.text: Which of the following completes the sequence: Red, Blue, Green, _____?

options.text: Option A: Yellow, as it is the next primary color (4)
Option B: Orange, due to its position in the spectrum (2)
Option C: Purple, by following a blending pattern (1)
Option D: Violet, assuming an alphabetical order (0)

items.text: A man walks 10 miles north, turns right, and walks 10 miles east. How far is he from his starting point?

options.text: Option A: 14.14 miles, using the Pythagorean theorem (4)
Option B: 20 miles, as he walked that total distance (1)
Option C: 10 miles, considering only one direction (0)
Option D: 15 miles, assuming a linear path (2)

items.text: Which of the following words is an antonym of 'benevolent'?

options.text: Option A: Malevolent, as it means having ill will (4)
Option B: Kind, due to its similar meaning (0)
Option C: Generous, which is a synonym (1)
Option D: Empathetic, which is related but not opposite (2)

items.text: Which number comes next in the series: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, _____?

options.text: Option A: 36, as these are square numbers (4)
Option B: 30, by adding consecutive odd numbers (2)
Option C: 40, assuming a doubling pattern (0)
Option D: 34, by following a mistaken sequence (1)

items.text: If you have a bag with 50 red balls and 50 blue balls, what is the probability of picking out a red ball?

options.text: Option A: 50%, due to equal distribution (4)
Option B: 25%, considering a reduced sample (0)
Option C: 75%, assuming a skewed distribution (1)
Option D: 60%, based on incorrect assumptions (2)

items.text: Which of these shapes cannot be formed by folding a square piece of paper?

options.text: Option A: A cone, as it requires a circular base (4)
Option B: A rectangle, achievable with folds (0)
Option C: A triangle, possible through diagonal folds (1)
Option D: A smaller square, formed by equal folds (2)

items.text: What comes next in this pattern: 2, 3, 5, 8, 12, ...?

options.text: Option A: 17, adding consecutive numbers each time (4)
Option B: 16, by doubling the last number (1)
Option C: 14, using a pattern of subtraction (0)
Option D: 15, by maintaining a different pattern (2)

items.text: In a race, John is twice as fast as Jeff. If John finishes in 10 minutes, how long does Jeff take?

options.text: Option A: 20 minutes, as Jeff is half as fast (4)
Option B: 15 minutes, assuming a smaller difference (1)
Option C: 10 minutes, if they both maintain pace (0)
Option D: 25 minutes, considering a miscalculation (2)

items.text: Which word is synonymous with 'ostentatious'?

options.text: Option A: Showy, as it implies a display of wealth (4)
Option B: Humble, which is the opposite (0)
Option C: Simple, as it suggests minimalism (1)
Option D: Plain, indicating lack of decoration (2)

items.text: What number completes the series: 3, 6, 12, 24, 48, ...?

options.text: Option A: 96, by doubling each previous number (4)
Option B: 72, following a sequence of additions (1)
Option C: 102, using a different growth factor (0)
Option D: 84, assuming an incorrect pattern (2)

items.text: If you rearrange the letters 'RAPET', you obtain the name of a(n):

options.text: Option A: Fruit, as it spells 'PEAR' (4)
Option B: Animal, due to a misinterpretation (0)
Option C: City, assuming a geographical name (1)
Option D: Country, following an unrelated assumption (2)

items.text: A rectangle has a length of 10 and a width of 5. What is the area?

options.text: Option A: 50, by multiplying length and width (4)
Option B: 15, by adding dimensions (0)
Option C: 40, assuming incorrect multiplication (1)
Option D: 25, using a different formula (2)

items.text: Which of the following shapes is three-dimensional?

options.text: Option A: Sphere, as it has volume (4)
Option B: Circle, which is flat (0)
Option C: Square, having no depth (1)
Option D: Triangle, a planar figure (2)

items.text: Which of the following sequences continues: 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, ...?

options.text: Option A: 13, following the Fibonacci sequence (4)
Option B: 10, by adding a constant number (0)
Option C: 15, based on a mistaken pattern (1)
Option D: 11, assuming an unrelated sequence (2)

items.text: What is the result of the following operation: (3 + 5) x 2?

options.text: Option A: 16, by following order of operations (4)
Option B: 13, assuming incorrect addition (0)
Option C: 14, through an error in multiplication (1)
Option D: 18, due to miscalculation (2)

items.text: If a week has 7 days, how many weeks are there in 42 days?

options.text: Option A: 6 weeks, by dividing total days by 7 (4)
Option B: 5 weeks, due to a counting error (1)
Option C: 8 weeks, assuming an incorrect calculation (0)
Option D: 7 weeks, from a miscounted sequence (2)

items.text: Which of the following is an example of a palindrome?

options.text: Option A: 'Racecar', as it reads the same backward (4)
Option B: 'Garden', due to incorrect assumption (0)
Option C: 'Computer', which does not reverse (1)
Option D: 'Science', following a mistaken pattern (2)

items.text: What completes the pattern: 1, 2, 4, 7, 11, ...?

options.text: Option A: 16, by adding consecutive numbers (4)
Option B: 14, using a different addition pattern (1)
Option C: 18, assuming an incorrect sequence (0)
Option D: 15, due to a miscalculation (2)

items.text: If all poodles are dogs and some dogs are not poodles, can we conclude that some poodles are not dogs?

options.text: Option A: No, all poodles are dogs (4)
Option B: Yes, some poodles are not dogs (0)
Option C: It depends on additional information (1)
Option D: Only some poodles are dogs (2)

items.text: A farmer has 17 cows, all but 8 die. How many are left?

options.text: Option A: 8, as those are the surviving cows (4)
Option B: 9, assuming a misinterpretation (1)
Option C: 17, as none actually died (0)
Option D: 7, due to incorrect subtraction (2)

items.text: Which letter comes next in the series: Z, X, V, T, ...?

options.text: Option A: R, following a pattern of subtracting two alphabet positions (4)
Option B: S, due to a mistaken sequence (0)
Option C: Q, based on an incorrect assumption (1)
Option D: P, assuming a doubling pattern (2)

items.text: What is the result of the operation: 9 - (4 + 2)?

options.text: Option A: 3, by applying order of operations (4)
Option B: 5, due to incorrect subtraction (0)
Option C: 6, following a miscalculation (1)
Option D: 4, assuming a different operation (2)

items.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of a cube?

options.text: Option A: Each face is a square, providing equal dimensions (4)
Option B: It has circular faces, which is incorrect (0)
Option C: It is flat, which is a wrong assumption (1)
Option D: It has triangular surfaces, which is not true (2)

items.text: Complete the analogy: Finger is to Hand as Leaf is to?

options.text: Option A: Tree, as a leaf is part of a tree (4)
Option B: Forest, which is a broader category (0)
Option C: Branch, which is a misconception (1)
Option D: Ground, assuming an unrelated analogy (2)

Your responses suggest above-average cognitive performance; you may excel in challenging intellectual environments.
